stem: The patient's recent ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. This finding is MOST consistent with an acute [BLANK] myocardial infarction.

itemContext.sbar: S: Patient is a 68-year-old male presenting with severe chest pain that started approximately 2 hours ago. He describes it as a crushing pressure in the center of his chest. B: Patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a 30-pack-year smoking history. He takes lisinopril and atorvastatin daily. A: ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Troponin levels are pending. Patient is diaphoretic and anxious. R: Recommend immediate cardiology consultation and initiation of MONA protocol.

rationale.incorrect: The ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF is indicative of an inferior wall myocardial infarction, which is typically caused by occlusion of the right coronary artery or the left circumflex artery.
clinicalPearls: ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF suggests an inferior wall MI.
Reciprocal ST-segment depression in lateral leads (I, aVL) can further support the diagnosis of inferior MI.
Right ventricular involvement should be considered in inferior MIs, especially with hypotension.

questionTrap.rationale1: An anterior wall MI typically presents with ST-segment elevation in leads V1-V4.
questionTrap.rationale2: A lateral wall MI typically presents with ST-segment elevation in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6.
questionTrap.rationale3: A septal wall MI typically presents with ST-segment elevation in leads V1 and V2.

mnemonic.title: ECG Lead Locations
mnemonic.description: Remember ECG lead locations for different MI types: 'ALLS' - Anterior, Lateral, Lateral, Septal. Inferior (II, III, aVF) is often paired with Right Ventricular (RV) MI.
